'''Leslie Allen Jordan''' (April 29, 1955 – October 24, 2022) was an American actor, comedian, writer, and singer.<ref name="ATC">{{Cite news |first1=Ari |last1=Shapiro |first2=Mia |last2=Venkat |title=On 'Company's Comin',' Leslie Jordan And Gospel Greats Dance For Joy |url=https://www.npr.org/2021/04/02/983846257/on-companys-comin-leslie-jordan-and-gospel-greats-sing-for-joy |access-date=April 3, 2021 |date=April 2, 2021 |work=[[All Things Considered]] |publisher=[[NPR]]}}</ref> His television roles include [[List of Will & Grace characters|Beverley Leslie]] on ''[[Will & Grace]]'' (2001–2006 and 2017–2020), several characters in the ''[[American Horror Story]]'' franchise (2013–2019), Sid on [[The Cool Kids (TV series)|''The Cool Kids'']] (2018–2019), Phil on ''[[Call Me Kat]]'' (2021–2022), and Lonnie Garr on ''[[Hearts Afire]]'' (1993–1995). On stage, he played Earl "Brother Boy" Ingram in the 1996 play ''Sordid Lives'', later portraying the character in the [[Sordid Lives|2000 film of the same name]]. During the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], Jordan became an [[Instagram]] contributor, amassing 5.8 million followers in 2020, and published his autobiography ''How Y'all Doing? Misadventures and Mischief from a Life Well Lived'' in April 2021.

==Early and personal life==
Jordan was born on April 29, 1955,<ref name=NYTimes-06-23-2020>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/23/style/leslie-jordan-instagram.html |title=It's a Wonderful Time to Be Leslie Jordan|first= Lindsey|last= Underwood|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 23, 2020|access-date=July 25, 2021|quote=Sober for 22 years, Mr. Jordan, 65...}}</ref> and was raised in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]].<ref name="tv.com">{{Cite web|url = http://www.tv.com/people/leslie-jordan/biography/|title = Leslie Jordan Biography|website = TV.com|access-date = October 29, 2014|archive-date = July 1, 2018|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180701030702/http://www.tv.com/people/leslie-jordan/biography/|url-status = dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thelesliejordan.com/site/bio/ |title=Biography|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407092451/http://thelesliejordan.com/site/bio/ |archive-date=April 7, 2014|url-status=dead|publisher=Leslie Jordan official website}}</ref> He graduated from [[Brainerd High School (Tennessee)|Brainerd High School]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cityscopemag.com/city-scope/bright-lights-big-city/ |title = Bright Lights, Big City – CityScope Magazine}}</ref> Jordan said his mother, Peggy Ann Jordan (née Griffin; 1935–2022),<ref name="peggymom">{{cite web |title=Peggy Jordan Obituary |url=https://www.dignitymemorial.com/obituaries/chattanooga-tn/peggy-jordan-10756271 |website=Dignity Memorial |access-date=October 25, 2022 |location=Chattanooga, TN |language=en}}</ref> was supportive and accepting, despite never truly understanding him. Jordan's father, Allen Bernard Jordan, was a major in the [[United States Army Reserve]] and died, along with two others, in the crash of a civilian [[Beechcraft Bonanza|Beechcraft Debonair]] airplane at [[Camp Shelby]], on March 31, 1967, when Jordan was almost 12 years old.<ref name="tv.com" /><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.newspapers.com/image/353461640/ |title=Bodies Of Three Men Found in Wreckage |date=April 2, 1967 |page=3 |newspaper=[[The Leaf-Chronicle]] |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref name="peggymom" /> In a 2014 interview, Jordan said that he had a difficult time growing up [[Southern Baptist Church|Southern Baptist]]. "I was baptized 14 times. Every time the preacher would say, 'Come forward, sinners!' I'd say, 'Oooh, I was out in the woods with that boy. I better go forward.'"<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.phillymag.com/g-philly/2014/03/12/girl-talk-gossiping-southern-baptist-sissies-star-leslie-jordan/|title = GIRL TALK: Gossiping With Southern Baptist Sissies Star Leslie Jordan |date = March 12, 2014|access-date = October 13, 2014|website = Philly Magazine|last = Middleton|first = Josh}}</ref>

Jordan moved to Los Angeles in 1982, where he became involved with drugs and alcohol and was arrested several times. He began to journal daily, which helped him recover from drug and alcohol abuse.<ref>{{Cite news|url= https://www.isthmus.com/arts/article.php?article=38022|title = Funnyman Leslie Jordan reflects on 'The Help', 'Will & Grace', 'Ski Patrol' and one-man comedy shows| last = Duerst |first = Austin |date = October 16, 2012|website = isthmus.com |access-date = July 31, 2015}}</ref> In 2010, Jordan told talk show host [[Wendy Williams]] that he had been sober for 13 years.<ref name="youtube.com">{{Cite news|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U-h8GEvRQlU|title = "Leslie Jordan's Famous Prison Mate," ''The Wendy Williams Show''|date = April 20, 2010|website = youtube.com |access-date = October 1, 2019}}</ref> In the same appearance, Jordan said that before he gave up drinking, he once shared a cell with [[Robert Downey Jr.]], and when they both appeared later on ''[[Ally McBeal]]'', Downey couldn't quite place where they had met before.<ref name="youtube.com" /> Jordan was [[Gay men|gay]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://instinctmagazine.com/exclusive-interview-we-cant-get-enough-of-southern-belle-leslie-jordan/|title=Exclusive Interview: We Can't Get Enough of Southern Belle Leslie Jordan|date=November 22, 2018|website=Instinct Magazine}}</ref> Early in the [[AIDS crisis]], Jordan became involved in [[AIDS Project Los Angeles]] (APLA) as a buddy and as a food delivery-person for [[Project Angel Food]].<ref name=":0" />

==Career==
===Film and television===
Jordan began his career in 1986, appearing as Malone in the adventure series ''[[The Fall Guy]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vulture.com/2022/10/leslie-jordan-dead-67-car-crash.html|title=Leslie Jordan, Delightful Actor and Social-Media King, Dead at 67|first=Zoe|last=Guy|date=October 24, 2022|website=Vulture}}</ref> He quickly became recognizable in the industry for his diminutive size and Southern drawl.<ref name="tv.com" /> He appeared as newspaper editor Mr. Blackly in the movie ''[[The Help (film)|The Help]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://chattanoogan.com/2012/2/19/219837/Emmy-Winner-Leslie-Jordan-Headlines.aspx|title = Emmy-Winner Leslie Jordan Headlines Tuesday Night Live May 15}}</ref> His television career includes guest appearances on ''[[Murphy Brown]]'', ''[[Designing Women]]'', ''[[Will & Grace]]'', ''[[Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman]]'', ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'', ''[[Caroline in the City]]'', ''[[Pee-Wee's Playhouse]]'', ''[[Reba (TV series)|Reba]]'', ''[[Boston Public]]'', ''[[Boston Legal]]'', ''[[Nash Bridges]]'', ''[[American Horror Story]]'', ''[[Perfect Strangers (TV series)|Perfect Strangers]]'', and ''[[Hearts Afire]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ew.com/movies/leslie-jordan-the-help-cast-rescued-puppy/|title=Leslie Jordan reveals how 'The Help' cast rescued a puppy — and who they named it after|website=EW.com|language=EN|access-date=April 2, 2020}}</ref> In 1990, Jordan portrayed the ski patrol director in ''[[Ski Patrol (1990 film)|Ski Patrol]]''.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.today.com/popculture/leslie-jordan-s-instagram-videos-are-beacon-funny-t177193|title='Will & Grace' actor's viral videos are a beacon of funny in the darkness|website=TODAY.com|date=March 31, 2020 |language=en|access-date=April 2, 2020}}</ref> In 2007, he guest-starred on the comedy drama ''[[Ugly Betty]]''<nowiki/> as celebrity-trasher Quincy Combs, and starred as Jesse Joe in the short-lived CW television program Hidden Palms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.towleroad.com/2007/05/screen_cap_lesl/|title=Screen Cap: Leslie Jordan On Hidden Palms – Towleroad Gay News|newspaper=Towleroad Gay News |date=May 31, 2007}}</ref>

On the television series ''Will & Grace,'' Jordan played [[Supporting characters on Will & Grace|Beverley Leslie]], [[Karen Walker (character)|Karen]]'s pretentious, poorly-closeted rival,<ref name=Atlanta /> for which he received an [[Emmy Award]] for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series]] at the [[58th Annual Primetime Emmy Awards]] in 2006. His [[Emmy Award]] earned him an invitation to present the awards for Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series and Outstanding Directing for a Comedy Series at the 2006 Emmy Awards with [[Cloris Leachman]] a week later.<ref>{{Cite book|title = My Trip Down the Pink Carpet|last = Jordan|first = Leslie|publisher = Simon and Schuster| year = 2008}}</ref> Jordan starred in the pilot episode of ''Laugh Out'', the world's first interactive, gay-themed comedy show.<ref name=Atlanta>{{cite press release| url= http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/atlanta-entertainment-company-to-produce-innovative-interactive-gay-themed-comedy-show-55898972.html |title= Atlanta Entertainment Company to Produce Innovative, Interactive Gay-Themed Comedy Show| website= prnewswire.com| date= May 2, 2015| location= Atlanta| access-date= July 31, 2015}}</ref> On August 18, 2014, Jordan became a housemate in the [[Celebrity Big Brother (British series 14)|fourteenth season]] of the British reality game show ''[[Celebrity Big Brother (British TV series)|Celebrity Big Brother]]''. He was the second person to leave the Big Brother house (August 29, 2014).<ref name="digitalspy.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/reality-tv/a592261/celebrity-big-brother-who-has-leslie-jordan-sent-to-the-scrapheap/|title=CBB: Who has Leslie sent to the Scrapheap?|website=[[Digital Spy]] |date=August 23, 2014}}</ref> In January 2015, Jordan guest-starred in the British sitcom ''[[Benidorm (British TV series)|Benidorm]]'' for two episodes, as the character Buck A. Roo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.itv.com/goodmorningbritain/articles/the-final-benidorm-for-sheila-reid|title=The final Benidorm for Sheila Reid|website=ITV}}</ref> On November 1, 2017, Jordan appeared in the new British television drama ''[[Living the Dream (UK TV series)|Living the Dream]]'', produced jointly by [[Sky UK|Sky]] and [[Big Talk Productions]], but branded as a Sky Original Production.<ref name= "florida">{{cite news |last=Dowell |first=Ben |url= http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2017-10-19/philip-glenister-and-lesley-sharp-are-brits-abroad-in-first-look-at-skys-new-florida-comedy-living-the-dream/ |title=Philip Glenister and Lesley Sharp are Brits abroad in first look at Sky's new Florida comedy Living the Dream |work=[[Radio Times]] |date=October 19, 2017 |access-date=February 16, 2018}}</ref> In 2018–2019, Jordan starred in the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] sitcom ''[[The Cool Kids (TV series)|The Cool Kids]]'', along with [[Martin Mull]], [[Vicki Lawrence]], and [[David Alan Grier]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Boedeker|first=Hal|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment/tv/tv-guy/os-et-fox-makes-room-for-veteran-performers-20180514-story.html|title=Fox makes room for veteran performers|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=May 14, 2018|access-date=May 15, 2018}}</ref>

On April 2, 2020, it was announced Jordan would play the series regular role of Phil in the Fox sitcom ''[[Call Me Kat]]'', along with [[Mayim Bialik]], [[Swoosie Kurtz]], [[Kyla Pratt]], and [[Cheyenne Jackson]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Petski|first=Denise|title=Leslie Jordan Joins 'Call Me Kat' Fox Comedy Series Starring Mayim Bialik|url=https://deadline.com/2020/04/leslie-jordan-call-me-kat-fox-comedy-series-mayim-bialik-1202898845/|website=Deadline Hollywood|access-date=April 2, 2020 |language=en |date=April 2, 2020}}</ref> The show premiered in January 2021. The same year, Jordan was a guest panelist on [[The Masked Singer (American season 6)|season six]] of ''[[The Masked Singer (American TV series)|The Masked Singer]]'' during Week 5 where he also did a performance of "[[This Little Light of Mine]]" as "Soft Serve".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/2022/10/24/7-times-leslie-jordan-was-hilarious-and-iconic|title=7 Times Leslie Jordan Was Hilarious and Iconic|date=October 24, 2022|website=www.advocate.com}}</ref> He later returned as a guest panelist in [[The Masked Singer (American season 7)|season seven]] and [[The Masked Singer (American season 8)|season eight]]. A posthumously-airing holiday episode of ''[[Lego Masters (American TV series)|Lego Masters]]'' was one of his final works before his death.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Malone |first1=Michael |title='Lego Masters: Celebrity Holiday Bricktacular' on December 19–21 |url=https://www.nexttv.com/news/lego-masters-celebrity-holiday-bricktacular-on-december-19-21 |website=Broadcasting & Cable |access-date=December 15, 2022 |date=September 7, 2022}}</ref>

===Theatre===
Jordan played Earl "Brother Boy" Ingram in ''[[Sordid Lives]]'', and also portrayed this character in the popular [[cult film]] of the same name. Jordan reprised the role in a [[Sordid Lives: The Series|televised spin-off]] of the movie, which aired on [[Logo (TV channel)|Logo]], where he played a character who is institutionalized in a mental hospital.<ref>{{cite news | first=Tim | last=Parks | title=The 'Sordid Lives' of 'Southern Baptist Sissies | url=http://www.gaylesbiantimes.com/?id=7957 | work=The Gay and Lesbian Times | date=August 17, 2006 | access-date=April 8, 2008 | url-status=usurped | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080302204936/http://www.gaylesbiantimes.com/?id=7957 | archive-date=March 2, 2008 }}</ref> He wrote and starred in the autobiographical play ''Lost in the Pershing Point Hotel'', which was also made into a motion picture. In 2004, he toured the country performing his one-man stage comedy, ''Like a Dog on Linoleum'', to generally favorable reviews.<ref>{{cite news | first= David C. |last= Nichols | title='Dog on Linoleum' finds firm footing | url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2004-oct-15-et-dog15-story.html | work=Los Angeles Times | date=October 15, 2004 | access-date=April 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal
| last        = Helbig
| first       = Jack
| date        = August 11, 2005
| title       = Like a Dog on Linoleum
| url         = http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/like-a-dog-on-linoleum/Content?oid=919582
| journal     = [[Chicago Reader]]
| access-date = April 2, 2014
}}</ref>

Jordan's first autobiographical stage show was called ''Hysterical Blindness and Other Southern Tragedies That Have Plagued My Life Thus Far'',<ref name=":0" /> with music and lyrics by [[Joe Patrick Ward]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LMIBAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA97|page=97|title=Theatre Reviews|date=June 13, 1994|magazine=New York Magazine|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/28/theater/review-theater-a-hollywood-soul-s-trip-from-tennessee.html|title=Review/Theater; A Hollywood Soul's Trip From Tennessee|date=May 28, 1994|website=The New York Times}}</ref> The production, in which Jordan was backed by a gospel choir singing satirical songs about racism and [[homophobia]], was produced [[off-Broadway]] at the [[SoHo Playhouse]] and ran for seven months. Next, he distilled his experiences growing up as an effeminate, tiny boy in [[Southern United States|the South]] and in show business into an autobiographical one-man show, ''My Trip Down the Pink Carpet''. During the opening of ''My Trip Down the Pink Carpet'', Jordan's microphone stopped working, but he kept on with the show like nothing happened; the show was a success.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |url=https://glreview.org/article/article-573/ |title=Leslie Jordan: from small screen to big stage |last = Freeman |first = Chris |date = 2009 |journal=The Gay and Lesbian Review |access-date=May 19, 2021}}</ref> After touring the nation for several months with the production, the show opened off-Broadway at the Midtown Theater on April 19, 2010. The show was produced by Jordan's friend, actress [[Lily Tomlin]]. Jordan announced on ''[[The Paul O'Grady Show]]'' that he would be bringing his show to London's [[Apollo Theatre]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tvmaze.com/characters/327089/paul-ogrady-live-host|title=Host – Paul O'Grady Live | TVmaze|website=www.tvmaze.com}}</ref>

===Music===
Jordan released the [[gospel music]] album ''Company's Comin''' in 2021.<ref name="ATC" />

===Social media===
At the time of his death, Jordan had accumulated 5.8 million Instagram followers. His following grew substantially in response to his comedy posts during the COVID-19 pandemic.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.cnn.com/videos/us/2020/04/25/leslie-jordan-anderson-cooper-instagram-quarantine-ac360-sot-vpx.cnn | work = CNN | title = Anderson Cooper cracks up at Leslie Jordan's life hack}}</ref>

==Death==
On October 24, 2022, at approximately 9:30 am [[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]], while driving to film scenes at the ''[[Call Me Kat]]'' set,<ref name="kat-death">{{cite news |title=Leslie Jordan Was Headed to Set of 'Call Me Kat' When He Died |url=https://www.tmz.com/2022/10/26/leslie-jordan-dead-dies-driving-call-me-kat/ |access-date=October 27, 2022 |work=TMZ |archive-url=https://archive.today/20221027004759/https://www.tmz.com/2022/10/26/leslie-jordan-dead-dies-driving-call-me-kat/ |archive-date=October 27, 2022 |language=en}}</ref> Jordan's car hit the side of a building at [[Cahuenga Boulevard]] and Romaine Street in [[Hollywood, Los Angeles|Hollywood]].<ref name="kat-death" /> He was believed to have experienced a medical episode that led to the crash. Jordan was pronounced dead at the scene.<ref>{{cite magazine|url = https://variety.com/2022/tv/obituaries-people-news/leslie-jordan-dead-will-and-grace-american-horror-story-1235412784/|title = Leslie Jordan, 'Will & Grace' and 'American Horror Story' Star, Dies at 67 in Car Accident|last = Shanfield|first = Ethan|date = October 24, 2022|access-date = October 24, 2022|magazine = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}</ref> He was 67 years old.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 26, 2022 |title=Leslie Jordan's cause of death 'deferred' by L.A. coroner pending more investigation |url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2022-10-26/leslie-jordan-death-car-accident-crash-call-me-kat |access-date=October 26, 2022 |website=Los Angeles Times |language=en-US}}</ref>

In January 2023, an autopsy report revealed Jordan died by "sudden [[Cardiac arrest|cardiac dysfunction]]".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Leslie Jordan Died from 'Cardiac Dysfunction' Before Crashing Car into Building |url=https://www.tmz.com/2023/01/19/leslie-jordan-cause-of-death-cardiac-dysfunction-crash-car-into-building/ |access-date=January 19, 2023 |website=TMZ |date=January 19, 2023 |language=en}}</ref> According to the [[Los Angeles County Department of Medical Examiner-Coroner|Los Angeles County Coroner's Office]], Jordan died from sudden cardiac dysfunction due to [[Arteriosclerosis|arteriosclerotic cardiovascular disease]]. There was no evidence of alcohol or other drugs in Jordan's system. At the time of his death, he had been sober for more than two decades.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Leslie Jordan's Cause of Death Confirmed |url=https://people.com/tv/leslie-jordan-cause-of-death-confirmed/ |access-date=January 19, 2023 |magazine=People |language=en}}</ref>

==Awards==
In 2021, Jordan received [[GALECA]]: The Society of LGBTQ Entertainment Critics' Timeless Star award, the group's career achievement honor given to "an actor or performer whose exemplary career is marked by character, wisdom and wit."<ref>{{cite web |last=Beresford|first=Trilby|title=Dorian Film Awards: Chloe Zhao and 'Nomadland' Win Top Honors From LGBTQ Entertainment Critics|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/dorian-film-awards-chloe-zhao-and-nomadland-win-top-honors-from-lgbtq-entertainment-critics-4168143/|website=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=February 7, 2022 |language=en |date=April 8, 2021}}</ref> Jordan accepted the award, previously bestowed on [[Jane Fonda]], [[Meryl Streep]], [[John Waters]], [[Harvey Fierstein]], [[Lily Tomlin]], [[Dame Angela Lansbury]], and [[Sir Ian McKellen]], in the Society's [[Dorian Awards]] 'Toast' TV.<ref>{{cite web |last=Arnold|first=JW|title='Nomadland,' 'Ma Rainey' Top LGBTQ Critics Awards|url=https://southfloridagaynews.com/Film/nomadland-ma-rainey-top-lgbtq-critics-awards.html/|website=South Florida Gay News|access-date=February 7, 2022|language=en |date=April 22, 2021}}</ref> He also won an Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series [[Emmy Awards|Emmy Award]] in 2006 for his part as Beverley Leslie in ''[[Will & Grace]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Will & Grace |url=https://www.emmys.com/shows/will-grace |access-date=October 27, 2022 |website=Television Academy |language=en}}</ref>
